message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), with an enlarged prostate and difficulty initiating urination. Among the options, hyperplasia of lateral prostatic lobe tissue is the most common cause of BPH. Infiltrating neoplasia and lymphocytic infiltration are less likely causes, and hypertrophy of the middle prostatic lobe tissue is a less common variant of BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is often associated with an enlarged prostate that is symmetrically enlarged and nontender with a rubbery consistency. BPH commonly affects the lateral and middle lobes of the prostate. Infiltrating neoplasia of bladder urothelium and lymphocytic infiltration of anterior prostatic lobe stroma are unlikely causes for the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is most commonly caused by hyperplasia of lateral prostatic lobe tissue. The other options are less likely to cause BPH symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia, which typically involves the lateral lobes of the prostate. Option (B) is unlikely as it involves the bladder rather than the prostate. Option (C) may cause obstruction of the bladder neck but is less common than hyperplasia of the lateral lobes. Option (D) is not a common cause of urinary symptoms in older men. The PSA level is not suggestive of neoplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which typically involves the lateral lobes of the prostate. Option A is the only choice that mentions lateral tissue involvement, while the other options are not commonly associated with BPH. The normal PSA level also suggests BPH rather than prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the digital rectal examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which commonly affects the lateral lobes of the prostate. Infiltrating neoplasia of the bladder urothelium would present with bladder symptoms, not difficulty initiating urination. Hypertrophy of the middle lobe tissue and lymphocytic infiltration of the anterior lobe stroma are less common causes of BPH. The normal prostate-specific antigen level also suggests BPH rather than prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is most commonly caused by hyperplasia of the lateral prostatic lobe tissue. Infiltrating neoplasia of bladder urothelium and lymphocytic infiltration of anterior prostatic lobe stroma are not common causes of BPH. Hypertrophy of middle prostatic lobe tissue can also cause BPH, but the symmetric enlargement and rubbery consistency suggest hyperplasia of the lateral lobes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including difficulty initiating urination and waking up at night to urinate, suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Among the options, only hyperplasia of lateral prostatic lobe tissue is associated with BPH. Infiltrating neoplasia of bladder urothelium is associated with bladder cancer, not BPH. Hypertrophy of the middle prostatic lobe tissue is less common than hyperplasia of lateral prostatic lobe tissue as a cause of BPH. Lymphocytic infiltration of anterior prostatic lobe stroma is not a known cause of BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which commonly occurs in the lateral prostatic lobe tissue. Infiltrating neoplasia of bladder urothelium would present with hematuria, and lymphocytic infiltration of anterior prostatic lobe stroma is a rare condition. Hypertrophy of the middle prostatic lobe tissue is unlikely to cause the patient's symptoms. The laboratory studies show a normal prostate-specific antigen level, which is common in BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is the most common cause of lower urinary tract symptoms in men over the age of 50. Hyperplasia of the lateral prostatic lobes is the most common site for BPH. None of the other options are consistent with the patient's presentation of BPH.
